editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE BASSET-Table. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by Her Majeſty's Servants.
By the Author of the Gameſter.
LONDON: Printed for William Turner at the Angel at Lincolns-Inn-Back-Gate; and Sold by J. Nutt near Stationers-Hall, 1706. Price 1s. 6d.

div.head: To the Right Honourable ARTHUR Lord ALTHAM, BARON of ALTHAM, In the Kingdom of IRELAND.
div.p:
POetry, in its firſt Inſtitution, was principally deſign'd to Correct, and rectify Manners. Thence it was that the Roman and Athenian Stages were accounted Schools of Divinity and Morality; where the Tragick Writers of thoſe Days inſpired their Audiences with Noble and Heroick Sentiments, and the Comick laugh'd and diverted them out of their Vices; and by rediculing Folly, Intemperence, and Debauchery,
gave them an Indignation for thoſe Irregularities, and made them purſue the oppoſite Virtues.

This caus'd the Dramatic Poets, in ancient Times, not only to be reverenc'd by the lower ſort of People, but highly Eſteem'd and Courted by Perſons of the firſt Rank; and tho' the Writers of latter Ages, have, in a greater Meaſure, not to ſay in a ſcandelous Manner, deviated from the Foot-ſteps, and Examples of their Predeceſſors; yet have they found Protection and Favour with thoſe, who have been ſo Generous as to aſcribe the Faults of the Poets to the Degeneracy of the Age wherein they liv'd.

This conſideration, my Lord, has imbolden'd me to this Addreſs, for tho' on the one Hand I am ſenſible, that the following Piece does little Merit your Lordſhip's Patronage; yet your innate Goodneſs and Generoſity give me hopes, that your Lordſhip will Pardon this Intruſion, in
which I have the Examples of all thoſe that wrote before me to bear me out. I heartily wiſh this Play were more worthy of your Lordſhip's Acceptance: Yet ſo much, I hope, will be forgiven to the fondneſs of a Mother for her Production; if, I ſay, in its Favour, that through the whole Piece, I have had a tender regard to good Manners, and by the main Drift of it, endeavour'd to Redicule and Correct one of the moſt reigning Vices of the Age. I might ſay, as many of my Brethren have done upon ſlighter Grounds, that this Play has had the good Fortune to Pleaſe and Divert the Niceſt, and Politeſt Part of the Town; but I ſhould ſet little Streſs on their Applauſe, had I not ſome reaſon to depend upon your Lordſhip's Approbation, whoſe Judgement, Penetration and Diſcernment, are alone ſufficient to do full Juſtice to a performance of this Kind.

And now, my Lord, if I follow'd the beaten Road of Dedicators, it would naturally Engage me in a Panegirick, upon your Lordſhip's Perſonal Virtues, and thoſe of your Noble and Pious Family; but I ſhall purpoſely decline a Talk to which I freely own my Ability is Unequal, and which, tho' manag'd by a Maſterly Pen, would make your Modeſty ſuffer. Therefore I ſhall conclude, with begging your Lordſhip's leave to Subſcribe my ſelf, with all imaginable Reſpect and Sincerity.

closer.signed: Your Lordſhip's moſt Obedient, and moſt Devoted Humble Servant,

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.l: IN all the Faces that to Plays Reſort,
Whether of Country, City, Mob or Court;
I've always found that none ſuch hopes Inſpire,
As you—dear Brethren of the Upper Tire.
Poets in Prologues, may both Preach and Rail,
Yet all their Wiſdom, nothing will avail,
Who writes not up to you, 'tis ten to one will fail.
Your thundring plaudit 'tis that deals out Fame,
You make Plays run, tho' of themſelves but Lame:
How often have we known your Noiſe Commanding,
Impoſe on your Inferior Maſters Underſtanding;
Therefore, Dear Brethren, (ſince I am one of you)
Whether adorn'd in Grey, Green, Brown or Blue,
This day ſtand all by me, as I will fall by you,
And now to let—
The poor Pit ſee how Pinky's Voice Commands,
Silence—Now rattle all your Sticks, and clap your grimy Hands▪
I greet your Love—and let the vaineſt Author ſhow,
Half this Command on clearer Hands below,
Nay, more to prove your Intereſt, let this Play live by you.
So may you ſhare good Claret with your Maſters,
Still free in your Amours from their Diſaſters;
Free from poor Houſe-keeping, where Peck is under Locks▪
Free from Cold Kitchings, and no Chriſtmas Box:
So may no long Debates i'th' Houſe of Commons,
Make you in the Lobby Starve, when hungar Summons:
But may your plentious Vails come flowing in,
Give you a lucky hit, and make you Gentlemen;
And thus preferr'd, ne'er fear the World's Reproaches,
But ſhake your Elbows with my Lord, and keep your Coaches:

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: THis goodly Fabrick to a gazing Tarr,
Seems Fore and Aft, a Three Deckt-man oſ War.
Abaft, the Hold's the Pit, from thence look up,
Aloft! that Swabber's Neſt, that's the Main-Top.
Side-boxes mann'd with Beau, and modiſh Rake,
Are like the Fore-caſtle, and Quarter-Deck.
Thoſe dark diſguiſed, advent'rous, black-nos'd few,
May paſs for Gunners, or a Fire-ſhip's Crew.
Some come like Privateers a Prize to ſeize,
And catch the French within the Narrow Seas.
The Orange-Ladies, Virgins of Renown,
Are Powder-Monkies running up and down.
We've here our Calms, our Storms, and proſp'rous Gales,
And ſhift our Scenes as Seamen ſhift their Sails.
The Ship's well mann'd, and not ill Woman'd neither,
So Ballaſt'd and Stow'd, my Lads, ſhe'll bear the Weather.
But greater Dangers ventring Players alarm,
This Night's Engagement's worſe than any Storm.
The Poet's Captain, but half dead with fright,
She leaves her Officers to maintain the Fight;
Yon'd middle Teer with Eighteen Pounders mauls us,
That Upper-Deck with Great and Small-Shot gauls us.
But from this Lower-Teer moſt Harm befals,
There's no oppoſing their prevailing Balls.
As either Foe or Friend their Chain-ſhot flies,
We ſink or ſwim, we Conquer, Fall or Riſe.
To fit and rig our Ships much Pains we take;
Grant we may now a Saving-Voyage make.
Here we're Embark'd, and as you Smile or Frown,
You are our Stars, by You we Live or Drown.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.label: Mrs. Lucas,

div.stage:
Scene. Lady Reveller
• s Lodgings in Covent-Garden; the Time; Four of the Clock in the Morning.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: A large Hall, a Porter with a Staff, ſeveral Chairs Waiting, and Footmen a-ſleep, with Torches and Flambeauxs ſtanding about the Room.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: CErtainly they'l Play all Night, this is a curſed Life.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: How long have you liv'd with your Lady?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A Month, too long by thirty Days, if this be her way of living; I ſhall be dead before the Year's out; ſhe Games all Night, and Sleeps all Day.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: As long as you ſleep, what's Matter?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: But I do not, for while ſhe ſleeps, I'm Employ'd in Howdee's, from one end of the Town to the other.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: But you reſt while ſhe's Gaming; What would you do, if you led my Life? This is my Lady's conſtant Practice

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your Lady keeps a Baſſet Table, much good may do you with your Service—Hark, they are broke up. [within.] ha, hy, my Lady Gamewel's Chair ready there—Mr. Sonica's Servant (The Footmen wake in a hurry.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Foot.
sp.p: Where the Devil is my Flambeaux?

sp.speaker: 2d. Foot.
sp.p: So-hey—Robin, get the Chair ready, my Lady's coming; ſtay, ſtay, let me light my Flambeaux.

sp.speaker: 3d. Foot.
sp.p: [waking] Hey, hoa, what han't they done Play yet?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: They are now coming down, but your Lady is gone half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: 3d. Foot.
sp.p: The Devil ſhe is, why did not you call me?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I did not ſee you.

sp.speaker: 3d. Foot.
sp.p: Was you Blind?—She has loſt her Money, that's certain—She never flinches upo naW inning-Hand—her Plate and Jewels Walks to Morrow to repleniſh her Pocket—a Pox of Gaming, I ſay.
[Within.] Mr. Looſeall's Man—

sp.speaker: 4th Foot.
sp.p: Here—So-ho, who has ſtole my Flambeaux?
[Within.] My Lady Umbray's Coach there.—

sp.speaker: 5th Foot.
sp.p: Hey! Will, pull up there

div.stage: Enter Lady Reveller and Alpiew, her Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lady Raffle is horridly out of humour at her ill Fortune, ſhe loſt 300 l.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: She has generally ill luck, yet her Inclination for Play is as ſtrong as ever.—Did your Ladyſhip win, or loſe, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I won about 50 l.—prethee what ſhall we do, Alpiew? 'Tis a fine Morning, 'tis pity to go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: What does your Ladiſhip think of a Walk in the Park?—The Park is pleaſant in a Morning, the Air is ſo very ſweet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I don't think ſo; the ſweetneſs of the Park is at Eleven, when the Beau Monde makes their Tower there, 'tis an unpoliſh'd Curioſity to walk when only Birds can ſee one.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Madam! Your Uncle—now for a Sermon of two Hours.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard Plainman, in a Night-Gown as from Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: So Niece! I find you're reſolv'd to keep on your courſe of Life; I muſt be wak'd at Four with Coach, Coach, Chair, Chair; give over for ſhame, and Marry, Marry, Niece.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now would I forfeit the Heart of my next Admirer, to know the cauſe of this Reproach. Pray, Uncle, explain'd your ſelf; for I proteſt I can't gueſs what Crime I have unhappily committed to merit this advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How can you look me in the Face, and ask me that Queſtion? Can you that keep a Baſſet-Table, a publick Gaming-Houſe, be inſenſible of the ſhame on't? I have often told you how much the vaſt concurſe of People, which Day and Night make my Houſe their Rendevouze, incommode my Health; your Apartment is a Parade for Men of all Ranks, from the Duke to the Fidler, and your Vanity thinks they all pay Devoir to your Beauty—but you miſtake, every one has his ſeveral end in Meeting here, from the Lord to the Sharper, and each their ſeperate Intereſt to Admire—ſome Fools there may be, for there's ſeldom a crowd without.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Malice—ſome Fools? I can't bear it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis very affronting, truly Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, is it not Alpiew?—Yet, now I think on't, 'tis the defect of Age to rail at the Pleaſure's of Youth, therefore I ſhall not diſorder my Face with a frown about it. Ha, ha, I hope, Uncle, you'l take peculiar care of my Couſin Valeria, in diſpoſing of her according to the Breeding you have given her.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The Breeding I have given her! I would not have her have your Breeding, Miſtreſs, for all the Wealth of England's Bank; no, I bread my Girl in the Country, a ſtranger to the Vices of this Town, and am reſolv'd to Marry her to a Man of Honour, Probity and Courage.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What the Sea Captain, Uncle? Faugh, I hate the ſmell of Pitch and Tarr; one that can Entertain one with nothing but Fire and Smoak, Larboard and Starboard, and t'other Bowl of Punch, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: And for every fault that ſhe commits he'll condemn her to the Bilboes, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I fancy my Couſin's Philoſophy, and the Captain's Couragious Bluſter, will make Angelick Harmony.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Yes, Madam, ſweeter Harmony than your Sept & Le ••
Fops, Rakes and Gameſters; give me the Man that ſerves my Country, that preſerves both my Eſtate and Life—Oh, the glorious Name of Soldier; if I were Young, I'd go my ſelf in Perſon, but as it is—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: You'll ſend your Daughter—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Yes, Minx, and a good Dowry with her, as a reward for Virtue like the Captains.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe, Sir, Mrs. Valeria ſhould not like him?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll ſuppoſe no ſuch thing, Miſtreſs, ſhe ſhall like him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, there tis now, indeed, Uncle, your're too poſitive.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And you to Impertinent: Therefore I reſolve to quit your Houſe; you ſhan't keep your Revels under the Roof where I am.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'd have you to know, Sir, my Lady keeps no Revels beneath her Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Mrs. Pert, or I ſhall diſplay your Quality in its proper Colours.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I don't care, ſay your worſt of me, and ſpare not; but for my Lady—my Lady's a Widdow, and Widdows are accountable to none for their Actions—Well, I ſhall have a Husband one of thoſe days, and be a Widow too, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Not unlikely, for the Man will hang himſelf the next day, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: And if any, Uncle, pretends to controul my Actions—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: He'd looſe his labour, I'm certain—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'd treat him—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Don't provoke me, Houſwife, don't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Be gone, and wait in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The Inſolence of a Servant, is a great Honour to the Lady, no doubt; but I ſhall find a way to humble you both.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Lookee, Unkle, do what you can, I'm reſolv'd to follow my own Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Which infallibly carries you to Noiſe, Nonſence, Foppery and Ruin; but no matter, you ſhall out of my Doors, I'll promiſe you, my Houſe ſhall no longer bear the Scandalous Name of a Baſſet Table: Husbands ſhall no more have cauſe to date their Ruin from my Door, nor cry there, there my Wife Gam'd my Eſtate away—Nor Children Curſe my Poſterity, for their Parents knowing my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No more threatning, good Unkle, act as you pleaſe, but don't ſcold, or I ſhall be oblig'd to call Alpiew again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Very well, very well, ſee what will come on't; the World will cenſure thoſe that Game, and, in my Conſcience, I believe not without Cauſe.
sp.l: For ſhe whoſe Shame, no good Advice can wake,
When Money's wanting, will her Virtue Stake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Advice! Ha, ha, ridiculous Advice. (Enter Lady Lucy) No ſooner rid of one miſchief, but another follows—I foreſee this is to be a day of Mortification, Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Uncle's gone, you may come in, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Fye, Couſin, does it become you to Laugh at thoſe that give you Council for your good?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For my good! Oh, mon cour? Now cannot I Divine what 'tis, that I do more than the reſt of the World, to deſerve this blame.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nor I, for the Soul of me.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Shou'd all the reſt of the World follow your Ladyſhip's Example, the order of Nature would be inverted, and every good, deſign'd by Heaven, become a Curſe, Health and Plenty no longer would be known among us.—You croſs the purpoſe of the Day and Night, you Wake when you ſhould Sleep, and make all who have any dependence on you, Wake while you Repoſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Bleſs me, may not any Perſon Sleep when they pleaſe?

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p:
No, there are certain Hours, that good Man
••••… Modeſty and Health require your Care; for Exam
•••… diſorderly Hours are neither Healthful nor Modeſt— 〈…〉 not Civil to make Company wait Dinner for your 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, does any body Dine before four a Clock in London? For my part I think it an Ill-bred Cuſtom, to make my Appetite Pendulum to the Twelfth hour.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Beſides, 'tis out of Faſhion to Dine by Day light, and ſo I told Sir Richard yeſterday, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: No doubt, but you did, Mrs. Alpiew; and then you entertain ſuch a Train of People, Couſin, that my Lady Reveller is as noted as a publick Ordinary, where every Fool with Money finds a Welcome.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Would you have me ſhut my doors againſt my Friends—Now ſhe is jealous of Sir James Courtly. (aſide.) Beſides, is it poſſible to paſs the Evenings without Diverſions.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No certainly—

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: I think the Play-houſe, the much more innocent and commendable Diverſion.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To be ſeen there every Night, in my Opinion, is more deſtructive to the Reputation.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Well, I had rather be noted every Night in the front Box, then, by my abſence, once be ſuſpected of Gaming; one ruins my Eſtate and Character, the other diverts my Temper, and improves my Mind. Then you have ſuch a number of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh Cupid, is it a Crime to have a number of Lovers? If it be, 'tis the pleaſanteſt Crime in the World. A Crime that falls not every day, to every Womans Lot.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: I dare be poſitive every Woman does not wiſh it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Becauſe wiſhes have no Effect, Couſin, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Methinks my Lord Worthy's Aſſiduity might have baniſh'd the admiring Croud by this time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Baniſh'd 'em? Oh, Mon cour! what pleaſure is there in one Lover; 'tis like being ſeen always in one Suit of Cloaths; a Woman, with one Admirer, will ne'er be a Reigning Toaſt.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: I am ſure thoſe that Encourage more, will never have the Character of a Reigning Virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſlight the malicious Cenſure of the Town, yet defy it to aſperſe my Verture; Nature has given me a Face, a Shape, a Mein, an Air for Dreſs, and Wit and Humour to ſubdue. And ſhall I loſe my Conqueſt for a Name.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, and among the unfaſhionable ſort of People too, Madam; for Perſons of Breeding and Quality will allow, that Gallantry and Virtue are not inſeperable.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: But Coquetry and Reputation are, and there is no differerence in the Eye of the World, between having really committed the Fault, and lying under the Scandal; for, my own part, I would take as much Care to preſerve my Fame, as you would your Virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A little pains will ſerve you for that, Couſin; for I never once heard you nam'd—A Mortification would break my Heart, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: 'Tis better never to be nam'd, than to be ill ſpoke of; but your Reflections ſhall not Diſorder my Temper. I could wiſh, indeed, to convince you of your Error, becauſe you ſhare my Blood; but ſince I ſee the Vanity of the attempt, I ſhall deſiſt.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, here's my Lord Worthy, Sir James Courtly, and Enſign Lovely, coming down; will your Ladyſhip ſee them?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now have I a ſtrong Inclination to Engage Sir James, to diſcompoſe her Gravity; for if I have any Skill in Glances, ſhe loves him—but then my Lord Worthy is ſo peeviſh ſince our late Quarrel, that I'm afraid to Engage the Knight in a Ducl; beſides, my Abſence, I know, will teize him more, therefore, upon Conſideration, I'le retire. Couſin Lucy; Good Morrow. I'le leave you to better Company, there's a Perſon at hand may prevent your Six-a-Clock Prayers.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ha! Sir James Courtly—I muſt own I think him agreeable—but am ſorry ſhe believes I do. I'le not be ſeen; for if what I ſcarce know my ſelf be grown ſo viſible to her, perhaps, he too may Diſcover it, and then I am loſt.
sp.l: While in the Breaſt our Secrets cloſe remain,
'Tis out of Fortunes power to give us Pain.

div.stage: Enter Lord Worthy, Sir James, Enſign Lovel.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha! was not that Lady Lucy?

sp.speaker: Enſign.
sp.p: It was—ah, Sir James, I find your Heart is out of Order about that Lady, and my Lord Worthy languiſhes for Lady Reveller.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And thou art ſick for Valeria, Sir Richard's Daughter. A poor diſtreſled Company of us.

sp.speaker: Enſign,
sp.p: 'Tis true, that little ſhe-Philoſopher has made me do Pennance more heartily than ever my ſins did; I deſerve her by meer Dint of Patience. I have ſtood whole hours to hear her Aſſert that Fire cannot Burn, nor Water Drown, nor Pain Afflict, and forty ridiculous Syſtems—and all her Experiments on Frogs, Fiſh—and Flies, ha, ha, ha, without the lcaſt Contradiction.

sp.speaker: Enſign.
sp.p: Contradiction, no, no, I allow'd all ſhe ſaid with undoubtedly, Madam,—I am of your mind, Madam, it muſt be ſo—natural Cauſes, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I think it is a ſupernatural cauſe which Enables thee to go thro' this Fatigue, if it were not to raiſe thy Fortune, I ſhould think thee Mad to purſue her; but go on and proſper, nothing in my Power ſhall be wanting to aſſiſt you—My Lord Worthy—your Lordſhip is as Melancholy as a loſing Gameſter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Faith, Gentlemen, I'm out of Humour, but I don't know at what.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Why then I can tell you, for the very ſame reaſon that made your Lordſhip ſtay here to be Spectator of the very Diverſion you hate—Gaming—the ſame Cauſe makes you uneaſy in all Company, my Lady Reveller.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Thou haſt hit it, James, I confeſs I love her Perſon, but hate her Humours, and her way of Living; I have ſome reaſons to believe I'm not indifferent to her, yet I deſpair of fixing her, her Vanity has got ſo much the Miſtreſs of her Reſolution; and yet her Paſſion for Gain furmounts her Pride, and lays her Reputation open to the World. Every Fool that has ready Money, ſhall dare to boaſt himſelf her very humble Servant; 'ds Death, when I could cut the Raſcal's Throat.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: your Lordſhip is even with her one Way, for you are as teſty as ſhe's vain, and as fond of an opportunity to Quarrel with her, as ſhe of a Gaming Acquaintance; my Opinion is, my Lord, ſhe'll ne're be won your Way.
sp.l: To gain all Women there's a certain Rule,
If Wit ſhould ſail to pleaſe, then Act the Fool;
And where you find ſimplicity not take,
Throw off Diſguiſes—and Profeſs the Rake;
Obſerve which Way their chiefeſt Humours run,
They're by their own lov'd, can't the ſureſt Way undone.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Thou'rt of a happy temper, Sir James, I wiſh I could be ſo too; but ſince I can't add to your Diverſion, I'll take my leave, good Morrow, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: This it is to have more Love than Reaſon about one; you and I Lovely will go on with Diſcretion, and yet I fear it's in Lady Lucy's Power to baniſh it.

sp.speaker: Enſign.
sp.p: I find Mrs. Sago, the Drugſters Wife's Intereſt, begins to ſhake, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And I fear her Love for Play begins to ſhake her Husband's Baggs too—faith, I am weary of that Intreague, leſt I ſhould be ſuſpected to have a hand in his Ruin.

sp.speaker: Enſign.
sp.p: She did not loſe much to Night, I believe; preethy, Sir James, what kind of a temper'd Woman is ſhe? Has ſhe Wit?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That ſhe has—A large Portion, and as much Cunning, or ſhe could never have manag'd the old Fellow ſo nicely; ſhe has a vaſt Paſſion for my Lady Reveller, and endeavours to mimick her in every thing—Not a ſute of Cloaths, or a Top-knot, that is not exactly the ſame with hers—then her Plots and Contrivances to ſupply theſe Expences, puts her continually upon the Rack; yet to give her her due, ſhe has a fertile Brain that Way; but come, ſhall we go home and ſleep two or three Hours, at Dinner I'll introduce you to Capt. Hearty, the Sea Officer, your Rival that is to be, he's juſt come to Town.

sp.speaker: Enſign.
sp.p: A powerful Rival, I fear, for Sir Richard reſolves to Marry him to his Daughter; all my hopes lyes in her Arguments, and you know Philoſophers are very poſitive—and if this Captain does but happen to Contradict one Whimſical Notion, the Poles will as ſoon join, as they Couple, and rather then yield, ſhe would go to the Indies in ſearch of Dampier's Ants.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, ſhe is no Woman if ſhe Obeys.
sp.l: Women like Tides with Paſſions Ebb and Flow,
And like them too, their ſource no Man can know.
To watch their Motions, is the ſafeſt Guide,
Who hi • s their Humour, Sails with Wind and Tide.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt ACT.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: GOod Morrow.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Good Morrow.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Good Morrow, good Morrow, is that all your buſineſs here; What means that Affected Look, as if you long'd to be examin'd what's the Matter.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: The Capricio's of Love, Madamoſelle; the Capricio's of Love.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Why—are you in Love?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: I—in Love! No, the Divel take me if ever I ſhall be infected with that Madneſs, 'tis enough for one in a Family to Fall under the whimſical Circumſtances of that Diſtemper. My Lord has a ſufficient Portion for both; here—here—here's a Letter for your Lady, I believe the Contents are not ſo full of Stars and Darts, and Flames, as they us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lady will not concern her ſelf with your Lord, nor his Letters neither, I can aſſure you that.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: So much the better, I'le tell him what you ſay—Have you no more?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Tell him it is not my fault, I have done as much for his Service, as lay in my Power, till I put her in ſo great a Paſſion, 'tis impoſſible to Appeaſe her.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Very good—my Lord is upon the Square, I promiſe ye, as much inraged as her Ladiſhip to the full. Well, Mrs. Alpiew, to the longeſt Day of his Life he fwears, never to forget Yeſterday's Adventure, that's given him perfect, perfect Liberty.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I believe ſo—What was it, pray?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I'll tell you; 'twas a matter of Conſequence, I aſſure you, I've known Lovers part for a leſs Triffle by half.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No Diſgreſſions, but to the point, what was it?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: This—my Lord, was at the Fair with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: In a Raffling-ſhop ſhe ſaw a young Gentleman, which ſhe ſaid was very handſom—At the ſame time, my Lord, prais'd a young Lady; ſhe redoubles her Commendations of the Beau—He enlarges on the Beauty of the Bell; their Diſcourſe grew warm on the ſubject; they Pauſe; ſhe begins again with the Perfections of the Gentleman; he ends with the ſame of the Lady; Thus they perſu'd their Arguments, ſtill finding ſuch mighty Charms in their new Favourites, till they found one another ſo Ugly—ſo Ugly—that they parted with full Reſolutions never to meet again.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pleaſant; well, if you have no more to tell me, adieu.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Stay a Moment, I ſee my Lord coming, I thought he'd follow me. Oh, Lovers Reſolutions—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: So, have you ſeen my Lady Reveller? (To Buckle.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha! Mrs. Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: There's your Lordſhip's Letter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: An Anſwer! She has done me very much Honour.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lord, I am commanded—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Hold a little, dear Mrs. Alpiew.
sp.stage: (All this while he is opening the Letter, thinking it from the Lady.)

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord, ſhe would not—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Bequiet, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I am very ſorry—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But a moment—Ha, why, this is my own Letter.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord—what, ſhe'd not receive it then?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: How durſt you ſtay ſo long.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhip not to harbour an ill Opinion of me, I oppoſed her anger with my utmoſt Skill, prais'd all your Actions, all your Parts, but all in Vain.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Enough, Enough, Madam, ſhe has taken the beſt method in the World—Well, then we are ne'er to meet again?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I know not that, my Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am over-joy'd at it, by my Life I am, ſhe has only prevented me; I came a purpoſe to break with her—

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: (aſide) Yes, ſo 'twas a ſign by the pleaſure you diſcover'd, in thinking ſhe had writ to you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, ſhe has entertain'd you with the Cauſe of this?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No, my Lord, never mention'd a Syllable, only ſaid, ſhe had for ever done with you; and charg'd me, as I valued her favour, to receive no Meſſage nor Letter, from you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: May I become the very'ſt Wretch alive, and all the Ills immaginable fall upon my Head, if I ſpeak to her more; nay, ever think of her but with Scorn—Where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: In her Dreſſing-room.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: There let her be, I am weary of her fantaſtick Humours, affected Airs, and unaccountable Paſſions.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: For half an Hour. (Aſide)

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Do you know what ſhe's a doing?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I believe, my Lord, trying on a Mantua; I left her with Mrs. Pleatwell, and that us'd to hold her a great while, for the Woman is ſaucily Familiar with all the Quality, and tells her all the Scandal.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And conveys Letters upon occaſion; 'tis tack'd to their Profeſſion—But, my Lady Reveller may do what ſhe pleaſes, I am no more her Slave, upon my Word; I have broke my Chain—She has not been out then ſince ſhe Roſe?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nay, if ſhe has, or has not, 'tis the ſame thing to me; ſhe may go the end of the World, if ſhe will; I ſhan't take any pains to follow her—Whoſe Footman was that I met?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I know not, my Lord, we have ſo many come with How-dee's, I ne'er mind them.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You are uneaſy, Child, come, I'll not detain you, I have no curioſity, I proteſt I'm ſatisfied if ſhe's ſo, I aſſure ye, let her deſpiſe me, let her hate me, 'tis all one, adieu. (Going.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lord, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Mrs Alpiew, let me beg one favour of you, (turns back.) not to ſay I was here.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'll do juſt as you pleaſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Do that then, and you'll oblige me,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I will. (Is going, and comes back often.)

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Don't forget.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip may depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Hold, now I think on't—Pray •• ll her you did ſee me, do ye hear?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tell her how indifferent ſhe is to me in every reſpect.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I ſhan't fail.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tell her every thing, juſt as I expreſt it to you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Adieu (going.)

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Now, I think on't, Mrs Alpiew, I have a great mind ſhe ſhou'd know my Sentiments from my own Mouth.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, I can't promiſe you that.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Becauſe ſhe has expreſly forbid your admittance.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I'd ſpeak but one Word with her.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Pugh, prethee do, let me ſee her, (intreating Mrs Alpiew.)

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: So now, all this mighty rage ends in a begging Submiſſion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Only tell her I'm here.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Why ſhould you deſire me to meet her Anger, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Come, you ſhall oblige me once.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Oh, dear, my Lord, you have ſuch a command over your Servant, I can refuſe nothing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Have you been at the Goldſmiths about the Bills, for I am fix'd on Travelling.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip's ſo diſturb'd, you have forgot you Countermanded me, and ſend me hither.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p:
Juſt as I told your Lordſhip, ſhe fell in a moſt violent Paſſion, at the bare mention of your Name; tell him,
ſaid ſhe, in a heroick Strain, I'll never ſee him more, and command him to quit that Room, 'cauſe I'm coming to't.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tyrant, curſe on my Follies, ſhe knows her Power; well, I hope, I may walk in the Gallery; I would ſpeak with her Uncle.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: To be ſure, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Learn, Miſtreſs, learn, you may come to make me Mad in time, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Go Fool, follow your Lord.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, I'll ſwear, Alpiew, you have given me the Vapours for all Day.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, if you had ſeen him, you muſt have had Compaſſion; I would not have ſuch a Heart of Adamant for the World; poor Lord, ſure you have the ſtrangeſt Power over him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Silly—one often Fanices one has Power, when one has none at all; I'll tell the Alpiew, he vex'd me ſtrangely before this grand Quarrel; I was at Picquet with my Lady Love-Witt four Nights ago, and bid him read me a new Copy of Verſes, becauſe, you know, he never Plays, and I did not well know what to do with him; he had ſcarce begun, when I being eager at a Pique, he roſe up, and ſaid, he believ'd I lov'd the Muſick of my own Voice, crying Nine and Twenty, Threeſcore, better than the ſweeteſt Poetry in the Univerſe, and abruptly left us.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: A great Crime, indeed, not to read when People are at a Game they are oblig'd to talk to all the while.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Crime, yes, indeed was it, for my Lady loves Poetry better than Play, and perhaps before the Poem had been done had loſt her Money to me. But, I wonder, Alpiew, by what Art 'tis you engage me in this Diſcourſe, why
ſhou'd I talk of a Man that's utterly my Averſiou—Have you heard from Mrs. Sago this Morning?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam, ſhe never ſails; ſhe has ſent your Ladiſhip the fineſt Cargo made up of Chocolate, Tea, Montifiaſco Wine, and 50 Rarities beſide, with ſomething to remember me, good Creature, that ſhe never forgets. Well, indeed, Madam, ſhe is the beſt natur'd Woman in the World; it grieves me to think what Sums ſhe loſes at Play.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh fye, ſhe muſt, a Citizen's Wife is not to be endur'd amongſt Quality; had ſhe not Money, 'twere impoſſible to receive her—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, I muſt ſay that of you Women of Quality, if there is but Money enough, you ſtand not upon Birth or Reputation, in either Sex; if you did, ſo many Sharpers of Covent-Garden, and Miſtreſles of St. James's, would not be daily admitted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Peace, Impertinence, you take ſtrange Freedoms.
Why in ſuch haſt Couſin Valeria. [Stopping her.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh! dear Couſin, don't ſtop me, I ſhall loſe the fineſt Infect for Deſection, a huge Fleſh Fly, which Mr. Lovely ſent me juſt now, and opening the Box to try the Experiment away it flew.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am glad the poor Fly eſcap'd; will you never be weary of theſe Whimſies?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Whimſies! natural Peiloſophy a Whimſy! Oh, the unlearn'd World.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ridiculous Learning?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Ridiculous, indeed, for Women; Philoſophy Sutes our Sex, as Jack Boots would do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Cuſtom would bring them as much in Faſhion as Furbeloes, and Practice would make us as Valiant as e're a Hero of them all; the Reſolution is in the Mind,—Nothing can enſlave that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Stars! this Girl will be Mad, that's certain.
Mad • ſo Nero Baniſh'd Philoſophers from Rome, and the firſt Diſcoverer of the Antipodes was Condemn'd for a Heretick.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In my Conſcience, Alpiew, this pritty Creature's ſpoil'd. Well, Couſin, might I Adviſe, you ſhould beſtow your Fortune in Founding a College for the Study of Philoſophy, where none but Women ſhould be admitted, and to Immortalize your Name, they ſhould be call'd Vale •• ans, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What you make a Jeſt of, Id'e Execute, were Fortune in my Power.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: All Men would not be Excluded, the handſom Enſign, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In Love? Nay, there's no Philoſophy againſt Love, Solon for that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Piſha, no more of this Triffling Subject; Couſin, will you believe there's any thing without Gaul?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am ſatisfy'd I have one, when I loſe at Play, or ſee a Lady Addreſt when I am by, and 'tis equal to me, whether the reſt of the Creation have or not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, but I'le convince you then, I have diſſected my Dove—and poſitively I think the Vulgar Notion true, for I could find none.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Barbarous; kill'd your pritty Dove! [Starting.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Kill'd it! Why, what did you Imagine I bred it up for? Can Animals, Inſects or Reptils, be put to a Nobler uſe, than to improve our Knowledge? Couſin, I'll give you this Jewel for your Italian Grey-hound.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, to Cut to Pieces? Oh, horrid! he had need be a Soldier that ventures on you, for my part, I ſhould Dream of nothing but Inciſion, Diſſection and Amputation, and always fancy the Knife at my Throat.
Madam, here's Sir Richard, and a—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A— What, is it an Accident, a Subſtance, a Material Being, or, a Being of Reaſon?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I don't know what you call a Material Being; it is a Man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: P'sha, a Man, that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She'll prove by and by out of Diſcartes, that we are all Machines.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, do you ſee who obſerves you? My Lord walking in the Gallery, and every Minute gives a Peep.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Does he ſo? I'll fit him for Eves-dropping—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I like the Relation you have given me of your Naval Expedition, your Diſcourſe ſpeaks you a Manfit for the Sea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You had it without a flouriſh, Sir Richard, my Word is this, I hate the French, Love a handſome Woman, and a Bowl of Punch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Very Blunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This is my Daughter, Captain, a Girl of ſober Education; ſhe underſtands nothing of Gaming, Parks and Plays.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: But wanting theſe Diverſions, ſhe has ſupply'd the Vacancy with greater Follies. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Tite little Frigate, [Salutes her] Faith, I think, ſhe looks like a freſhman Sea-ſick—but here's a Gallant Veſſel—with all her Streamers out, Top and Top Gallant—with your leave, Madam, (Salutes her) who is that Lady, Sir Richard?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis a Niece of mine, Captain—tho' I am ſorry ſhe is ſo, ſhe values nothing that does not ſpend their days at their Glaſs, and their Nights at Baſſet, ſuch who ne'er did good to their Prince, nor Country, except their Taylor, Peruke-maker, and Perſumer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Sir, believe him not, I have a Paſſion, an extream Paſſion, for a Hero—eſpecially if he belongs to the Sea; methinks he has an Air ſo Fierce, ſo Piercing, his very Looks commands Reſpect from his own Sex, and all the Hearts of ours.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The Divel—Now, rather than let another Female have a Man to her ſelf, ſhe'll make the firſt Advances. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, we are preferr'd by you fine Ladies ſometimes before the ſprucer Sparks—there's a Conveniency in't; a fair Wind, and we hale out, and leave you Liberty and Money, two things the moſt acceptable to a Wife in Nature.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! ay, it is ſo pretty to have one's Husband gone Nine Months of the Twelve, and then to bring one home fine China, fine Lace, fine Muſlin, and fine Indian Birds, and a thouſand Curioſities.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: No, no, Nine is a little too long, ſix would do better for one of your Conſtitution, Mrs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what think you of a cruiſing Voyage towards the Cape of Matrimony, your Father deſigns me for the Pilot, if you agree to it, we'll hoiſt Sail immediately.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I agree to any thing dictated by good Senſe, and comprehended within the Borders of Elocution, the converſs I hold with your Sex, is only to improve and cultivate the Notions of my Mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What the Devil is ſhe going upon now? [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I preſume you'r a Mariner, Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have the Honour to bear the Queen's Commiſſion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray, ſpeak properly, poſitively, Laconically and Naturally.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So ſhe has given him a Broadſide already.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Laconically? Why, why, what is your Daughter? Sir Richard, ha

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
May I be reduc'd to Wooden-Shoes, if I can tell you, the Devil; had I liv'd near a College, the Haunts of ſome Pedaunt might have brought this Curſe upon me; but to have got my Eſtate in the City, and to have a Daughter run Mad after Philoſophy, I'll ne'er ſuffer it in
the rage I am in, I'll throw all the Books and Mathematical Inſtruments out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I dare ſay, Uncle, you have ſhook hands with Philoſophy—for I'm ſure you have baniſh'd Patience, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And you Diſcretion—By all my hatred for the French, they'll drive me Mad; Captain I'll expect you in the next Room, and you Mrs Laconick, with your Philoſophy at your Tail.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Shan't I come too, Uncle, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By Neptune, this is a kind of a whimſical Family; well, Madam, what was you going to ſay ſo poſitively and properly, and ſo forth?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I would have ask'd you, Sir, if ever you had the curioſity to inſpect a Mermaid—Or if you are convinc'd there is a World in every Star—We, by our Telliſcopes, find Seas, Groves and Plains, and all that; but what they are Peopled with, there's the Query.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let your next Contrivance be how to get thither, and then you'll know a World in every Star—Ha, ha, ſhe's fitter for Moorfields than Matrimony, pray, Madam, are you always infected, full and change, with this Diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How has my reaſon err'd, to hold converſe with an irrational Being—Dear, dear Philoſophy, what immenſe pleaſures dwell in thee!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, John, has got the Fiſh you ſent him in ſearch of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is it alive?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your Servant, your Servant, I would not loſe the Experiment for any thing, but the tour of the new World.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, is your Ladiſhip troubled with thefe Vagaries too; is the whole Houſe poſſeſt?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not I, Captain, the ſpeculative faculty is not my Talent; I am for the practick, can liſſen all Day, to hear you talk of Fire, ſubſtantial Fire, Rear and Front, and Line of Battle—admire a Seaman, hate the French,—love a Bowl of Punch? Oh, nothing ſo agreeable as your Converſation, nothing ſo Jaunty as a Sea Captain.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: So, this engages him to Play,—If he has either Manners or Money. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, give me the Woman that can hold me tack in my own Dialect—She's Mad too, I ſuppoſe, but I'll humour her a little. (aſide) Oh, Madam, not a fair Wind, nor a rich Prize, nor Conqueſt o're my Enemies, can pleaſe like you; accept my Heart without Capitulation—'Tis yours, a Priſoner at Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you muſt there contend with me; the Victory is not ſo eaſy as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh fye, my Lord, you won't fight for one you hate and deſpiſe? I may truſt you with the Captain, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This muſt be her Lover—And he is Mad another way; this is the moſt unaccountable Family I ever met with. (aſide) Lookye, Sir, what you mean by contending I know not; but I muſt tell you, I don't think any Woman I have ſeen ſince I came aſhoar worth Fighting for. The Philoſophical Gimcrack I don't value of a Cockle Shell—And am too well acquainted with the danger of Rocks and Quick-ſands, to ſteer into t'others Harbour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: He has diſcover'd her already; I, only I, am blind. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
But, Sir, if you have a mind to a Breathing, here tread upon my Toe, or ſpeak but one Word in favour of the
〈◊〉 , or againſt the Courage of our Fleet, and my Sword will ſtart of its ſelf, to do its Maſter, and my Country, Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: How ridiculous do I make my ſelf—Pardon me, Sir, you are in the right. I confeſs I ſcarce knew what I did.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I thought ſo, poor Gentleman, I pitty him; this is the effect of Love on ſhoar—When do we hear of a Tarr in theſe • its, longer then the firſt freſh Gale—Well, I'll into Sir Richard, Eat with him, Drink with him: but to Match into his Generation, I'd as ſoon Marry one of his Daughters Mermaids.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Was ever Man ſo ſtupid as my ſelf? But I will rouſe from this Lethargick Dream, and ſeek elſewhere what is deny'd at home, abſence may reſtore my Liberty.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, did you ſee my Keecky.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Keecky, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: My Wife, you muſt know, I call her Keecky, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Not I, indeed—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Nay, pray my Lord, ben't angry, I only want her, to tell her what a Preſent of fine Wine is ſent her juſt now; and ha, ha, ha, ha, what makes me Laugh—Is that, no Soul can tell from whence it comes.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Your Wife knows, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: No more than my ſelf, my Lord—We have often Wine and Sweet-meats; nay, whole pieces of Silk, and the duce take me, if ſhe could deviſe from whence; nay, ſometimes ſhe has been for ſending them back again, but I cry'd, whoſe a Fool then—

sp.speaker: Lord,
sp.p: I'm ſure thou art one in perfection, and to me inſupportable. [Going]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: My Lord, I know your Lordſhip has the Priviledge of this Houſe, pray do me the Kindneſs if you find my Wife to ſend her out to me.

I ne'er ſaw ſo much of this Lord's Humour before; he is very Surly Methinks—Adod there are ſome Lords of my Wives Acquaintance, as Civil and Familiar with me, as I am with my Journeyman—Oh! here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh Puddy, ſee what my Lady Reveller has preſented me withal.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Hey Keecky, why ſure you Riſe—as the ſaying is, for at Home there's Four Hampers of Wine ſent ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: From whence, Dear Puddy?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Nay, there's the Jeſt, neither you nor I know. I offer'd the Rogue that brought it a Guinea to tell from whence it came, and he Swore he durſt not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, if he had I'd never have Employ'd him again. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: So I gave him Half a Crown, and let him go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: It comes very Opportunely pray Puddy ſend a Couple of the Hampers to my Lady Revelleras a ſmall Acknowledgement for the Rich Preſent ſhe has made me.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: With all my Heart, my Jewel, my Precious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Puddy, I am ſtrangely oblig'd to Mrs. Alpiew, do, Puddy, do, Dear Puddy.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Will ye, then? Do, Dear Puddy, do, lend me a Guinea to give her, do. [Hanging upon him in a Wheedling Tone.]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: P'ſhaw, you are always wanting Guineas, I'll ſend her Half a Pound of Tea, Keecky.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Tea—ſha—ſhe Drinks Ladies Tea; do, Dear Pudd, do; can you deny Keecky now?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Well, well, there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Mrs. Alpiew, will you pleaſe to lay the Silk by for me, till I ſend for it, and accept of That?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, I'll be careful of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Thank ye, Borrow as much as you can on't, Dear Alpiew. [Aſide to her.]

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I muſt Raiſe a Summ for Baſſet againſt Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Preethy Keecky, what kind of Humour'd Man is Lord Worthy? I did but ask him if he ſaw thee, and I Thought he would ſnapp'd my Noſe off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh a meer Woman, full of Spleen and Vapours, he and I never agree.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Adod, I thought ſo—I gueſt'd he was none of thy Admirers—Ha, ha, ha, why there's my Lord Courtall, and my Lord Harncit, bow down to the Ground to me wherever they meet me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, the Goldſmith has ſent in the Plate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Very well, take it along with the Silk. [Aſide to her.]

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Here's the Jeweller; Madam, with the Diamond Ring, but he don't ſeem willing to leave it without Money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Humph? I have a ſudden Thought, bid him ſtay, and bring me the Ring—Now for the Art of Wheedling.—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: What are you Whiſpering about? Ha? Precious.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Mrs. Alpiew ſays, a Friend of her has a Diamond Ring to Sell, a great Penny-worthand I know you love a Bargain Puddy.

sp.stage: Enter Alpiew, gives her the Ring.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: P'ſhaw, I don't care for Rings; it may be a Bargain, and it may not; and I can't ſpare Money; I have Paid for a Lot this Morning; conſider Trade muſt go forward, Lambkin.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: See how it Sparkles.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Nay, Puddy, if it be not Worth your Money I don't deſire you to Buy it; but don't it become my Finger, Puddy? See now.—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Ah! that Hand, that Hand it was which firſt got hold of my Heart; well what's the Price of it; Ha, I am raviſh'd to ſee it upon Keecky's Finger.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: What did he ſay the Price was? [To Alpiew.]

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Two Hundred Guineas, Madam. [Aſide to Mrs. Sago.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Threeſcore Pound, Dear Pudd, the Devils in't if he won't give that. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Threeſcore Pounds? Why 'tis Worth a Hundred Child, Richly—'tis Stole—'tis Stole.—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Stole? I'd have you to know the Owner is my Relation, and has been as great a Merchant as any in London, but has had the Misfortune to have his Ships fall into the Hands of the French, or he'd not have parted with it at ſuch a Rate; it Coſt him Two Hundred Guineas.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I believe as much; indeed 'tis very fine.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: So it is Keecky, and that Dear little Finger ſhall have it to let me Bite it; a little Tiny bit.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Dear Pudd, you Hurt me.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Here—I han't ſo much Money about me, but ther's a Bill, Lambkin—there now, you'll Buſs poor Puddy now, won't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Buſs him—yes that I will agen, and agen, and agen. Dear Pudd.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: You'll go Home with Puddy now to Dinner, won't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes—a—Dear Puddy, if you deſire it—I will—but—a—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: But I promis'd my Lady Reveller to Dine with her, Deary—do, let me Pudd—I'll Dine with you to Morrow-day.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, I'm ſure my Lady won't Eat a bit if ſhe don't ſtay.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Well, they are all ſo Fond of my Wife, by Keecky, ſhow me the Little Finger agen—Oh! Dear Little Finger, by Keecky. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: By own Pudd—Here Alpiew give him his Ring agen, I have my End, tell him 'tis to Dear.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: But what will you ſay when Mr. Sago. Miſſes it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I'll ſay—that it was two big for my Finger, and I loſt it; 'tis but a Crying-bout, and the good Man melts into Pity—
sp.l: I'th' Married State, this only Bliſs we find,
An Eaſie Husband to our Wiſhes kind.
Iv'e Gain'd my Point, Repleniſh'd Purſe once more,
Oh! caſt me Fortune on the Winning Shore.
Now let me Gain what I have Loſt before.

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: The Scene draws, and diſcovers Valeria with Books upon a Table, a Microſcope, putting a Fiſh upon it, ſeveral Animals lying by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: SHA! Thou fluttering Thing.—So now I've fix'd it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam, here's Mr. Lovely; I have introduc'd him as One of my Lady's Viſitors, and brought him down the Back-ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'm oblig'd to you, he comes opportunely.

div.p: Oh! Mr. Lovely, come, come here, look through this Glaſs, and ſee how the Blood Circulates in the Tale of this Fiſh.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Wonderful! but it Circulates prettier in this Fair Neck.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pſhaw—be quiet—I'll ſhow you a Curioſity, the greateſt that ever Nature made— [opens a Box] in opening a Dog the other Day I found this Worm.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Prodigious! 'tis the Joint-Worm, which the Learned talk of ſo much.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ay, the Lumbricus Latus, or Foeſcia, as Hippocrates calls it, or Vulgarly in Engliſh the Tape-Worm.—Thudaeus tells us of One of theſe Worms found in a Human Body 200 Foot long, without Head or Tail.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I wiſh they be not got into thy Brain. [Aſide.]
Oh you Charm me with theſe Diſcoveries.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Here's another Sort of Worm call'd Lumbricus teres Inteſtinalis.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I think the Firſt you ſhow'd me the greateſt Curioſity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis very odd, really, that there ſhould be every Inch a Joint, and every Joint a Mouth.—Oh the profound Secrets of Nature!

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrangely Surprizing.—But now let me be heard, for mine's the Voice of Nature too; methinks you neglect your ſelf, the moſt Perfect Piece of all her Works.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why? What Fault do you find in me?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: You have not Love enough; that Fire would Conſume and Baniſh all Studies but its own; your Eyes wou'd Sparkle, and ſpread I know not what, of Lively and Touching, o'er the whole Face; this Hand, when Preſs'd by him you Love, would Tremble to your Heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why ſo it does,—have I not told you Twenty Times I Love you,—for I hate Diſguiſe; your Temper being Adapted to mine, gave my 〈◊〉 the Firſt Impreſſion;—you know my Father's Poſitive,—but do not believe he ſhall Force me to any Thing that does not Love Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: But that Sea Captain Valeria.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If he was a Whale he might give you Pain, for I ſhould long to Diſſect him; but as he is a Man, you have no Reaſon to Fear him.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Conſent then to Fly with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, and leave my Microſcope, and all my Things, for my Father to break in Pleces?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns! Oh Heav'ns! he is coming up the Back-ſtairs. What-ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Humph, ha, cann't you put me in that Cloſet there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh no, I han't the Key.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I'll run down the Great Stairs, let who will ſee me. [Going.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh no, no, no, no, not for your Life;—here, here, here, get under this Tub.
sp.stage: Throws out ſome Fiſh in Haſt, and Turns the Tub over him.
sp.p: Sir, I'm here.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What, at your Whims—and Whirligigs, ye Baggage? I'll out at Window with them. [Throwing away the Things.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh Dear Father, ſave my Lumbricus Latus.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll Lamprey and Latum you; what's that I wonder? Ha? Where the Devil got you Names that your Father don't underſtand? Ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh my poor Worm! Now have you deſtroy'd a Thing, that, for ought I know, England cann't produce again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What is it good for? Anſwer me that?—VVhat's this Tub here for? Ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What ſhall I do now?—it is, a 'tis a—Oh Dear Sir! Don't touch the Tub,—for there's a Bear's Young Cub that I have brought for Diſſection,—but I dare not tonch it till the Keeper comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll Cub you, and Keeper you, with a Vengeance to you; is my Money laid out in Bears Cubs?—I'll drive out your Cub.—
sp.stage: Opens the Door, ſtands at a Diſtance off, and with his Cane, lifts up the Tub, Lovely riſes.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Oh the Devil diſcover'd, your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Oh! your Servant Sir—What is this your Bear's Cub? Ha Miſtreſs? His Taylor has lick'd him
nto Shape I find.—What did this Man do here? Ha Huſwife?—I doubt you have been ſtudying Natural Philoſophy with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he only brought me a ſtrange Fiſh, and hearing your Voice I was afraid you ſhould be Angry, and ſo that made me hide him.

sp.speaker: Sir. Rich.
sp.p: A Fiſh,—'tis the Fleſh I fear; I'll have you Married to Night.—I believe this Fellow was the Beggarly Enſign, who never March'd farther than from Whitehall to the Tower, who wants your Portion to make him a Brigadier, without ever ſeeing a Battel—Huſwife, ha—tho' your Philoſophical Cant, with a Murrain to you—has put the Captain out of Conceit, I have a Husband ſtill for you;—come along, come along, I'll ſend the Servants to clear this Room of your Bawbles,— (pulls her off) I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But the Servants won't, Old Gentleman, that's my Comfort ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'm glad they are gone, for the Duce take me if I cou'd hit the Way out.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha—Enſign! luckily met; I have been Labouring for you, and I hope done you a Piece of Service. Why, you look ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Surpriz'd! ſo wou'd you, Sir Harry, if you had been whelm'd under a Tub, without Room to Breath.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Under a Tub! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Twas the only Place of Shelter.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Come, come, I have a better Proſpect, the Captain is a very Honeſt Fellow, and thinks if you can bear with the Girl, you deſerve her Fortune; here's your
Part, [Gives a Paper] he'll give you your Cue, he ſtays at his Lodging for you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What's the Deſign?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That will tell you; quick Diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, Sir James, I know you have a Prolifick Brain, and will rely on your Contrivances, and if it ſucceeds the Captain ſhall have a Bowl of Punch large enough to ſet his Ship afloat.

div.stage: Lady Reveller, Lady Lucy, Mrs. Sago, appear.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The Tea-Table broke up already! I fear there has been but ſmall Recruits of Scandal to Day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Well, I'll ſwear I think the Captain's a Pleaſant Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That's becauſe he made his Court to her. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Uh—I Nauſeate thoſe Amphibious Creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Umph, ſhe was not Addreſs'd to.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: He ſeems neither to want Senſe, Honour, nor True Courage, and methinks there is a Beauty in his Plain Delivery.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: There ſpoke Sincerity without Affectation.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: How ſhall we paſs the Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Aye, Ladies, how ſhall we?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: You here! I thought you had Liſted your ſelf Volunteer under the Captain to Board ſome Prize, you whiſper'd ſo often, and ſneak'd out one after another.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Who would give one ſelf the Pains to Cruiſe Abroad, when all one Values is at Home?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: To whom is this Directed? Or will you Monopolize and Ingroſs us all?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: No,—tho' you would wake Deſire in every Beholder, I reſign you to my Worthy Friend.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: And the reſt of the Company have no Pretence to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: That's more than ſhe knows. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Beauty, like yours, wou'd give all Mankind Pretence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: So, not a Word to me; are theſe his Vows? [In an uneaſie Air.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: There's One upon the Teaze already. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Why, you are in Diſorder, my Dear; you look as if you had loſt a Trant-Leva: What have you ſaid to her, Sir James?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I ſaid, Madam? I hope I never ſay any Thing to offend the Ladies. The Devils in theſe Married Women, they cann't conceal their own Intriegues, though they Swear us to Secrecy. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: You miſtake, Couſin, 'tis his ſaying nothing to her has put her upon the Fret.

sp.speaker: Lady. Revel.
sp.p: Ah, your Obſervations are always Malicious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I deſpiſe them, Dear Lady Reveller, let's in to Picquet; I ſuppoſe Lady Lucy would be pleas'd with Sir James alone to finiſh her Remarks.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, if you remove the Cauſe, the Diſcourſe ceaſes.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: [Going up to her.] This you draw upon your ſelf, you will diſcover it. [To her.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes, your Falſhood.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Come my Dear, Sir James, will you make One at a Pool?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I'm to be at White's in Half an Hour, anon at the Baſſet-Table. I'm Yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, no, he cann't leave her. [Going, ſtill looking back.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: They play Gold, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: [Going up to Lady Lucy] Madam, were your Heart the Stake I'd Renounce all Engagements to win that, or retrieve my own.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I muſt like the Counterſtake very well er'e I play ſo high.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Sir James, hearkee, One Word with you.
sp.stage: Breaking from Lady Reveller's Hand, pulling Sir James by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I knew ſhe could not ſtir; I'll remove your Conſtraint, but, with my wonted Freedom, will tell you plainly—your Husband's Shop wou'd better become you than Gaming and Gallants. Oh Shame to Virtue, that we ſhou'd Copy Men in their moſt Reigning Vices!
sp.l: Of Virtue's wholeſome Rules unjuſtly we complain,
When Search of Pleaſures gives us greater Pain.
How ſlightly we our Reputation Guard,
Which loſt but once can never be Repair'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Farewel Sentences.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam— [Whiſpers her Lady.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: So then, you'd perſuade me 'twas the Care of my Fame.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nothing elſe I proteſt, my Dear little Rogue; I have as much Love as you, but I have more Conduct.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Well, you know how ſoon I forgive you your Faults.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Now to what Purpoſe have I Lied my ſelf into her good Graces, when I would be glad to be rid of her? [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p:
Booted and Spurr'd ſay you? Pray ſend him
up, Sir James; I ſuppoſe Truſty Buckle is come with ſome Diverting Embaſſy from your Friend.

div.stage: Enter Buckle in a Riding Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Buckle.
sp.p: Why in this Equipage?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Ah! Madam.—

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Farewel Friends, Parents, and my Country; thou Dear Play-houſe, and ſweet Park, Farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Farewel, why, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord and I am going where they never knew Deceit.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That Land is Inviſible, Buckle.

sp.speaker: Lady Revet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Were my Lord of my Mind your Ladiſhip ſhould not have had ſo large a Theme for your Mirth. Your Servant Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Well, but what's your Buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord charg'd me in his Name to take his Everlaſting Leave of your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Why, where is he a going pray?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: In ſearch of a Country where there is no Women.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh dear, why what have the Women done to him pray?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Done to him, Madam? He ſays they are Proud, Perfidious, Vain, Inconſtant, Coquets in England.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! He'll find they are everywhere the ſame.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: And this is the Cauſe of his Whimſical Pilgrimage? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: And this proceeds from your ill Uſage, Madam; when he left your Houſe,—he flung himſelf into his Coach with ſuch a Force, that he broke all the Windows,—as they ſay,—for my Part I was not there;—when he came Home he beat all his Servants round to be Reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Was you there, Buckle?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: No, I thank my Stars, when I arriv'd the Expedition was over;—in Haſte he Mounted his Chamber,—flung himſelf upon his Bed,—Burſting out into a Violent Paſſion,—Oh that ever I ſhould ſuffer my ſelf to be impos'd upon, ſaid he, by this Coquetiſh Beauty!

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Meaning me, Buckle, Ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Stay till I have finiſh'd the Piece, Madam, and your Ladiſhip ſhall judge;—ſhe's as Fickle as ſhe's Fair,—ſhe does not uſe more Art to Gain a Lover, ſaid he, than to deceive him when he is fix'd.—Humph. [Learing at her.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Pleaſant—and does he call this taking Leave?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: A Comical Adieu.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I'm not come to the Tragical Part of it yet, ſtarting from his Bed.—

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I thought it had been all Farce,—if there be any Thing Heroick in't I'll ſet my Face and look Grave.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Relation will require it, Madam, for I am ready to weep at the Repetition: Had you but ſeen how often he Travaſt the Room, [Acting it] heard how often he ſtamp'd, what diſtorted Faces he made, caſting up his Eyesthu • , Biting his Thumbs thus.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you'll make an Admirable Actor,—ſhall I ſpeak to the Patentees for you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: But pray how did this end?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: At laſt, Madam, quite ſpent with Rage, he ſunk down upon his Elbow, and his Head fell upon his Arm.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What, did he faint away?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: He did not die?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: No, Madam, but he fell aſleep.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh Brave Prince Pretti •… an.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: After Three Hours Nap he Wak'd—and calling haſtily—my Dear Buckle, ſaid he, let's to the End of the World; and try to ſind a Place where the Sun Shines not here and there at one Time—for 'tis not fit that it ſhould at once look upon Two Perſons whoſe Sentiments are ſo Different—She no longer regards my Pain, Ungrateful, Falſe, Inhumane, Barbarous Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Fooliſh, Fond, Believing, Eaſie Man; there's my Anſwer—Come, ſhall we to Piquet, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Madam, I han't half done—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Pray my Dear Lady Reveller, let's have it out, 'tis very Diverting—

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: He call'd me in a feeble Voice; Buckle, ſaid he, bring me my little Serutore—for I will write to Lady Reveller before I part from this Place, never to behold her more—what, don't you Cry, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Cry—No, no, go on, go on.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: 'Tis done, Madam—and there's the Letter.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p:
So, this Compleats the Narration. [Reads.]
Madam,
Since I cannot Live in a Place where there is a Poſſibility of ſeeing you without Admiring, I reſolve to Fly; I am going for Flanders; ſince you are Falſe I have no Buſineſs here—I need not deſcribe the Pain I feel, you are but too well Acquainted with that—therefore I'll chuſe Death rather than Return.— Adieu.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Can any Man in the World write more Tenderly, Madam? Does he not ſay 'tis Impoſſible to Love you, and go for Flanders? And that he would rather hear of your Death then Return.—

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Excellent, Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: What, do you Laugh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Who can forbear?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I think you ought to Die with Grief; I warrant Heaven will puniſh you all. [Going.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: But hearkee, Buckle, where are you going now?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: To tell my Lord in what Manner your Lady receiv'd his Letter; Farewel—now for Flanders.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: A fair Wind, and a good Voyage to you.
sp.stage: [As he goes out enter Lord Worthy.]

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord, here? So now may I have my Head Broke for my long Harangue if it comes out.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! Miraculous—my Lord, you have not finiſh'd your Campaign already, have you? Ha, ha, ha; or has the French made Peace at hearing of your Lordſhip's intended Bravery, and left you no Enemies to Combate?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My worſt of Foes are here—here, within my Breaſt; your Image, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh Dear, my Lord, no more of that Theme, for Buckle has given us a Surfeit on't already—even from your Breaking the Glaſſes of your Coach—to your falling faſt Aſleep. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The Glaſſes of my Coach! What do you mean, Madam—Oh Hell! [Biting his Thumbs.]

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Ruined quite.—Madam, for Heavens ſake what does your Ladiſhip Mean? I Li'd in every Syllable I told you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, if your Lordſhip has a Mind to Act it over agen we will Oblige you for once—Alpiew ſet Chairs—come, Dear Sago, ſit down—and let the Play begin—Buckle knows his Part, and upon Neceſſity cou'd Act yours too my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What has this Dog been doing? When he was only to deliver my Letter, to give her new Subject for her Mirth—Death, methinks I hate her,—Oh that I cou'd hold that Mind—what makes you in this Equipage? Ha! Sirrah? [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord, I, I, I, I,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Peace Villain—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hey—this is Changing the Scene—

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Who the Devil would Rack his Brains for theſe People of Quality, who like no Body's Wit but their own?— [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: If the Beating were Invention before, thou haſt it now in Reality; if Wars begin I'll Retire. They may agree better alone perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where did you learn this Rudeneſs, my Lord, to Strike your Servant before me?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: When you have depriv'd a Man of his Reaſon how can you blame his Conduct?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Reaſon—Egad—there's not Three Drams of Reaſon between you both—as my Cheek can teſtifie. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The Affront was meant to me—nor will I endure theſe Paſſions—I thought I had forbid your Viſits.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I thought I had Reſolv'd againſt them to.

sp.speaker: Alpiew.
sp.p: But Reſolutions are of ſmall force of either ſide. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Grant me but this One Requeſt and I'll remove this hated Object.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Upon Condition 'tis the laſt.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: It ſhall—I think it ſhall at leaſt—Is there a Happy Man for whom I am Deſpiſed?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I thought 'twas ſome ſuch ridiculous Queſtion; I'm of the Low-Church, my Lord, conſequently hate Confeſſors; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: And Penance to I dare Swear. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And every thing but Play.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dare you, the Subject of my Power—you, that Petition Love, Arraign my Pleaſures? Now I'm ſixt—and will never ſee you more.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Now wou'd any Body Swear ſhe's in Earneſt.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
I cannot bear that Curſe—ſee me at your Feet again, (Kneels) Oh! you have Tortur'd me enough,
take Pity now Dear Tyrant, and let my Suffering end.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I muſt not be Friends with him, for then I ſhall have him at my Elbow all Night, and ſpoil my Luck at the Baſſet-Table. [Aſide.] Either Cringing or Correcting, always in Extreams—I am weary of this Fatigue.
sp.l: He that wou'd gain my Heart muſt Learn the Way
Not to Controul, but readily to Obey.
For he that once Pretends my Faults to ſee,
That Moment makes himſelf all Faults to me.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: There's the Inſide of a Woman. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Gon—now Curſes on me for a Fool—the worſt of Fools—a Woman's Fool—
sp.l: Whoſe only Pleaſure is to feed her Pride,
Fond of her Self, ſhe cares for none beſide.
So true Coquets on their numerous Charms Diſplay,
And ſtrive to Conquer on purpoſe to betray.

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: Enter Lord Worthy and Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Well, my Lord. I have left my Cards in the Hand of a Friend to hear what you have to ſay to me. Love I'm ſure is the Text, therefore Divide and Subdivide as quick as you can.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Coud'ſt thou Infuſe into me thy Temper, Sir James, I ſhou'd have thy Reaſon too; but I am Born to Love this Fickle, Faithleſs Fair—what have I not Eſſay'd to Race her from my Breaſt? But all in Vain; I muſt have her, or I muſt not Live.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, if you are ſo far gone, my Lord, your Diſtemper requires an Able Phyſician—what think you of Loveley's bringing a File of Muſcqueteers, and carry her away, Via & Armis?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That Way might give her Perſon to my Arms, but where's the Heart?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: A Trifle in Competition with her Body.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The Heart's the Gem that I prefer.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Say you ſo my Lord? I'll Engage Three Parts of Europe will make that Exchange with you; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That Maxim wou'd hold with me perhaps in all but her, there I muſt have both or none; therefore Inſtruct, me Friend, thou who negligent in Love, keeps always on the Level with the Fair—what Method ſhou'd I take to Sound her Soul's Deſign? For tho' her Carriage puts me on the Rack when I behold that Train of Fools about her, yet my Heart will plead in her Excuſe, and Calm my Anger Spite of all Efforts.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Humph? I have a Plot, my Lord, if you'll comply with it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nothing of Force.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Whate're it be you ſhall be Witneſs of it, 'twill either Quench your Flame, or Kindle hers. I only will appear the Guilty; but here's Company, I'll tell you all within.

div.stage: Enter Captain and Lovely Dreſt like a Tar.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I'll expect you.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, Captain, How ſits the Wind between you and your Miſtreſs? Ha?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: North and by South, Faith; but here's one Sails full Eaſt, and without ſome unexpected Tornado, from the Old Man's Coaſt—he makes his Port I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I wiſh I were at Anchor once.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Why, thou art as arrant a Tar as if thou hadſt made an Eaſt-India Voyage, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Ay, am I not, Sir James? But Egad I hope the Old Fellow underſtands nothing of Navigation; if he does I ſhall be at a loſs for the Terms.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! no matter for Terms—look big, and Bluſter for your Country—deſcribe the Vigo Buſineſs—publick News will furniſh you with that, and I'll engage the Succeſs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, let me alone, I'll bear up with Sir Richard, and thou ſhalt Board his Pinnace with Conſent ne'er fear.—ho, here he comes full Sail.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee you; this is my Kinſman which I told you of, as ſoon as he Landed; I brought him to Kiſs your Hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I Honour you, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I thank you Sir,—I'm not for Compliments; 'tis a Land Language I underſtand it not; Courage, Honeſty, and Plain-dealing Truth, is the Learning of our Element; if you like that I am for ye. [Aſide to the Captain.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The Rogue does it to a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He's an improving Spark I find, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Like it, Sir, why 'tis the only Thing I do like, hang Compliments, and Court-Breeding, it ſerves only to make Men a Prey to one another, to Encourage Cowardice, and Ruin Trade—No, Sir, give me the Man that dares meet Death and Dinner with the ſame Appetite—
