one who rather than let in Popery, wou'd let out his Blood; to Maintain ſuch Men I'd pay Double Cuſtom; nay, all my Gain ſhou'd go for their Support. Gaptain lanch off a round Lie or Two. [Aſide to the Enſign.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The beſt Well-wiſher to his Country of an Engliſhman I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Richard, I wiſh the Nation were all of your Mind, 'twou'd give the Soldiers and the Sailors Life.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And make us Fight with Heart and Hand; my Kinſman, I'll aſſure you, fits your Principle to a Hair; he hates the French ſo much he ne'er fails to give them a Broadſide where'er he meets them; and has Brought in more Privateers this War than half the Captains in the Navy; he was the firſt Man that Boarded the French Fleet at Vigo—and in Gibraltar Buſineſs—the Gazettes will inform you of the Name of Captain Match.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Is this that Captain Match?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: For want of better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be Proud of being known to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And I of being Related to you, Sir,—I have a Daughter Young and Handſome, and I'll give her a Portion ſhall make thee an Admiral Boy; for a Soul like thine is fit only to Command a Navy—what ſay'ſt thou, art thou for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: So, 'tis done, ha, ha, ha. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A proſperous Gale I'faith.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I don't know, Sir Richard, mehap a Woman may not like me; I am Rough and Storm-like in my Temper, unacquainted with the Effeminacy of Co • rts; I was Born upon the Sea, and ſince I can remember never Liv'd Two Months on Shore; if I Marry my Wife muſt go Abroad, I promiſe you that.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Abroad Man? Why ſhe ſhall go to the Indies with the—Oh! ſuch a Son-in-Law—how ſhall I be Bleſt in my Poſterity? Now do I foreſee the Greatneſs of
my Grand-Children; the Sons of this Man ſhall, in the Age to come, make France a Tributary Nation.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Once in an Engagement, Sir, as I was giving Orders to my Men, comes a Ball and took off a Fellow's Head, and ſtruck it full in my Teeth; I wipp'd it up, clapp'd it into a Gun, and ſhot it at the Enemy again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Without the leaſt Concern?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Concern, Sir,—ha, ha, ha, if it had been my own Head I would have done the like.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Prodigious Effect of Courage!—Captain I'll fetch my Girl, and be here again in an Inſtant:—What an Honour 'twill be to have ſuch a Son!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, you outdo your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, the Old Knight's Tranſported.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I wiſh 'twas over, I am all in a Sweat; here he comes agrin.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll hear none of your Excuſes,—Captain your Hand,—there take her,—and theſe Gentlemen ſhall be Witneſſes, if they pleaſe, to this Paper, wherein I give her my whole Eſtate when I die, and Twenty Thouſand Pounds down upon the Nail; I care not whether my Boy be worth a Groat,—get me but Grandſons and I'm Rich enough.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Generouſly ſaid I'faith—much Good may do him with her.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I'll do my Eedeavour, Father, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I wiſh you Joy, Captain, and you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
That's Impoſſible;—can I have Joy in a Species ſo very different from miy own? Oh my Dear Lovely!—We were only form'd one for another;—thy Dear Enquiring Soul is more to me—than all theſe uſeleſs Lumps of Animated Clay: Duty compels my Hand,—but my Heart is ſubject only to my Mind,—
the Strength of that they cannot Conquer;—no, with the Reſolution of the Great Unparallell'd Epictetus,—I here proteſt my Will ſhall ne're aſſent to any but my Lovely.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Ay, you and your Will may Philoſophize as long as you pleaſe,—Miſtreſs,—but your Body ſhall be taught another Doctrine,—it ſhall ſo,—Your Mind,—and your Soul, quotha! Why, what a Pox has my Eſtate to do with them? Ha? 'Tis the Fleſh Huſwife, that muſt raiſe Heirs,—and Supporters of my Name;—and ſince I knew the getting of the Eſtate, 'tis fit I ſhou'd diſpoſe of it,—and therefore no more Excuſes, this is your Husband do you ſee,—take my Word for it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The outward empty Form of Marriage take
But all beyond I keep for Lovely's Sake.
Thus on the Ground for ever fix my Eyes;
All Sights but Lovely ſhall their Balls deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come, Captain,—my Chaplain is within, he ſhall do the Buſineſs this Minute: If I don't uſe the Authority of a Father, this Baggage will make me loſe ſuch a Son-in-law that the City's Wealth cann't purchaſe me his Fellow. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Thanks Dear Invention for this Timely Aid.
The Baits gon down, he's by himſelf betray'd.
Thus ſtill where Arts both True and Honeſt fail,
Deceitful Wit and Policy prevail.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To Death, or any Thing,—'tis all alike to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Get you in I ſay,—Huſſey, get you in. In my Conſcience my Niece has ſpoil'd her already; but I'll have her Married this Moment; Captain, you have bound
me ever to you by this Match, command me and my Houſe for ever.—But ſhall I not have your Company, Gentlemen, to be Witneſſes of this Knot, this joyful Knot?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes Faith, Sir Richard, I have too much Reſpect for my Kinſman to leave him—till I ſee him ſafe in Harbour; Ill wait on you preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I am engag'd in the next Room at Play, I beg your Pardon, Sir Richard, for an Hour; I'll bring the whole Company to Congratulate the Bride and Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Bride and Bridegroom? Congratulate me, Man: Methinks I already ſee my Race Recorded amongſt the foremoſt Heroes of my Nation.—Boys, all Boys,—and all Soldiers.
sp.l: They ſhall the Pride of France and Spain pull down,
And add their Indies to our Engliſh Crown.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, never was Man ſo Bigotted before;—how will this end when he diſcovers the Cheat? Ha, ha, won't you make One with the Ladies, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I don't care if I do venture a Piece or Two, I'll but diſpatch a little Buſineſs and meet you at the Table, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, Lady Lucy! Is your Ladiſhip reconccil'd to Baſſet yet? Will you give me leave to loſe this Purſe to you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I thank Fortune I neither wiſh, nor need it, Sir James; I preſume the next Room is furniſh'd with Avarice enough to ſerve you in that Affair, if it is a Burden to you; or Mrs. Sago's ill Luck may give you an Opportunity of returning ſome of the Obligations you lye under.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Your Sex, Madam, extorts a Duty from ours,
and a well-bred Man can no more refuſe his Money to a Lady, than his Sword to a Friend.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: That Superfluity of good Manners, Sir James, would do better Converted into Charity; this Town abounds with Objects—wou'd it not leave a more Glorious Fame behind you to be the Founder of ſome Pious Work; when all the Poor at mention of your Name ſhall Bleſs your Memory; than that Poſterity ſhou'd ſay you Waſted your Eſtate on Cards and Women?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Humph, 'tis pity ſhe were not a Man, ſhe Preaches ſo Emphatically. [Aſide.] Faith, Madam, you have a very good Notion, but ſomething too Early—when I am Old, I may put your Principles in Practice, but Youth for Pleaſure was deſign'd—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: The trueſt Pleaſure muſt conſiſt in doing Good, which cannot be in Gaming.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Every thing is good in its Kind, Madam; Cards are harmleſs Bits of Paper, Dice inſipid Bones—and Women made for Men.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Right, Sir James—but all theſe things may be perveted—Cards are harmleſs Bits of Paper in themſelves, yet through them what Miſchiefs have been Done? What Orphans Wrong'd? What Tradeſmen Ruin'd? What Coach and Equipage diſmiſt for them?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: But then, how many fine Coaches and Equipages have they ſet up, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Is it the more Honourable for that? How many Miſſes keep Coaches too? Which Arrogance in my Opinion only makes them more Eminently Scandalous—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! thoſe are ſuch, as have a Mind to be Damn'd in this S • ate, Madam—but I hope your Ladiſhips don't Rank them amongſt us Gameſters.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: They are Inſeparable, Sir James; Madam's Grandeur muſt be Upheld—tho' the Baker and Butcher ſhut up Shop.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! your Ladiſhip wrongs us middling Gentlemen there; to Ruin Tradeſmen is the Qualities Prerogative only; and none beneath a Lord can pretend to do't with an Honourable Air, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Their Example ſways the meaner Sort; I grieve to think that Fortune ſhou'd Exalt ſuch Vain, ſuch Vitious Souls—whilſt Virtue's Cloath'd in Raggs.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ah! Faith, ſhe'd make but a ſcurvy Figure at Court, Madam, the Stateſ-men and Politcians wou'd Suppreſs her quickly—but whilſt ſhe remains in your Breaſt ſhe's ſafe—and makes us all in Love with that Fair Covering.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! Fie, Fi, Sir James, you cou'd not Love one that hates your chief Direction.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I ſhou'd Hate it too, Madam, on ſome Terms that I cou'd Name.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: What wou'd make that Converſion pray?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Your Heart.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I cou'd pay that Price—but dare not Venture upon one ſo Wild— [Aſide.] Firſt let me ſee the Fruit e'er I take a Leaſe of the Garden, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, the beſt Way is to Secure the Ground, and then you may Manure and Cultivate it as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: That's a certain Trouble and uncertain Profit. and in this Affair; I prefer the Theory before the Practick But I detain you from the Table, Sir James—you are wanted to Tally—your Servant—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, if you leave me, Madam, the Devil will Tempt me—ſhe's gone, and now cann't I ſhake off the Thought of Seven Wins, Eight Loſes—for the Blood of me—and all this Grave Advice of hers is loſt, Faith—tho' I do Love her above the reſt of her Sex—ſhe's an exact Model of what all Women ought to be,—and yet your Merry little Coquetiſh Tits are very Diverting—well, now for Baſſet; let me ſee what Money have I about—me. Humph! about a Hundred Gnineas—half of which will ſet the Ladies to Cheating—falſe Parolies in Abundance.
sp.l: Each Trifling Toy wou'd Tempt in Times of Old,
Now nothing Melts a Womans Heart like Gold.
Some Bargains Drive, other's more Nice then they,
Who'd have you think they Scorn to Kiſs for Pay;
To Purchaſe them you muſt Loſe Deep at Play.
With ſeveral Women, ſeveral Ways Prevail;
But Gold's a certain Way that cannot Fail.

div.stage: The Scence Draws, and Diſcovers Lady Reveller, Mrs. Sago, and ſeveral Gentlemen and Ladies round a Table at Baſſet.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! Sir James, are you come? We want you to Tally for us.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: What Luck, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I have only won a Sept & Leva.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: And I have loſt a Trante & Leva—my Ill Fortune has not forſook me yet I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I go a Guinea upon that Card.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: You loſe that Card.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Mace Sir James's Card Double.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Seven wins, and Five loſes; you have loſt it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Agen?—ſure never was Woman ſo Unlucky—

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Knave wins, and Ten loſes; you have Won, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Clean Cards here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Burn this Book, 'thas an unluckly Air. (Tears them.) Bring ſome more Books.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! Captain—here ſet a Chair, come, Captain you, ſhall ſit by me—now if we can but Strip this Tarr. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Withal my Heart, Madam—come, what do you Play Gold?—that's ſomething High tho'—well a Guinea upon this Honeſt Knave of Clubs.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: You loſe it for a Guinea more.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: The Five Wins, and the Knave loſes.

sp.speaker: Lady. Revel.
sp.p: You have loſt it, Captain.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The Knave wins, for Two Guineas more, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Done Sir James.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Six Wins—Knave Loſes.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! the Devil, I'm Fac't, I had rather have loſt it all.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Nine wins, Queen loſes—you have won,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I'll make a Paroli—I Mace as much more; your Card loſes, Sir James, for Two Guineas, your's, Captain, loſes for a Guineas more.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Four wins, Nine loſes—you have Loſt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! I cou'd Tear my Fleſh—as I Tear theſe Cards—Confuſion—I can never win above a wretch'd Paroli; for if I puſh to Sept & Leva, tis gone.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Ace wins, Knave loſes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sink the Knave, I'll ſet no more on't.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Fac't agen—what's the meaning of this Ill-luck to Night? Bring me a Book of Hearts, I'll try if they are more Succeſsful, that on the Queen; yours and your Cards loſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Bring me a freſh Book; bring me another Book; bring me all Diamonds.
sp.stage: Looks upon them One by One, then throws them over her Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: That can never be lucky, the Name of Jewels don't become a Citizen's Wife. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: King wins, the Tray loſes.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: You have great Luck to Night, Mr. Sharper.

sp.speaker: Sharper.
sp.p: So I have Sir James—I have won Sonica every time.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: But if he has got the Nack of winning thus he ſhall ſharp no more here, I promiſe him. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Mace that.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Sir James, pray will you T • lly.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs Sago.
sp.p: Pray give me the Cards, Sir.
sp.stage: [Takes 'em and ſhuffles 'em, and gives 'em to him again.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I ſet that.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I ſet Five Guineas upon this Card, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Done Madam,—Five wins,—Six loſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Set that.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Five don't go, and Seven loſes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I Mace double.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I Mace that.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Three wins, Six loſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Mace, I Mace double, and that—Oh ye malicious Stars!—again.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Eight wins Seven loſes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So, this Trante & leva makes ſome Amends;—Adsbud I hate Cheating,—What's that falſe Cock made for now? Ha, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Rev.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Sago, if you begin to play foul.

sp.speaker: Mrs Sago.
sp.p: Rude Brute, to take Notice of the Slight of Hand in our Sex—I proteſt he wrongs me, Madam,—there's the Dernier, Stake,—and I'll ſet it all,—now Fortune Favour me, or this Moment is my laſt.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: There's the laſt of Fifty Pounds,—what's the Meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Now for my Plot, her Stock is low I perceive.
sp.stage: [Slips a Purſe of Gold into the Furbeloes of Lady Reveller's Apron.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I never had ſuch ill Luck,—I muſt fetch more Money: Ha; from whence comes this? This is the Genteeleſt Piece of Gallantry, the Action is Sir Harry's, I ſee by his Eyes.
sp.stage: Diſcovers a Purſe in the Furbeloes of her Apron.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nine wins, Six loſes

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I am ruin'd and undone for ever; oh, oh, oh, to looſe every Card, oh, oh, ho.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So there's one Veſſel ſprung aleek, and I am almoſt aſhoar—If I go on at this Rate, I ſhall make but a lame Voyage on't I doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Duce wins, King loſes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I Mace again,—I Mace Double, I mace again;—now the Devil blow my Head off if ever I ſaw Cards run ſo; Dam 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Fie, Captain, this Concern among the Ladies is indecent.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dam the Ladies,—mayn't I ſwear,—or tear my Cards if I pleaſe, I'm ſure I have paid for them; pray count the Cards, I believe there's a falſe Tally.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: No, they are Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Not to turn One Card! Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Madam, if you play no longer pray don't diſturb thoſe that do.—Come, Courage, Captain,—Sir James's Gold was very lucky;—who cou'd endure theſe Men did they not loſe their Money? [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bring another Book here;—that upon Ten,—and I Mace that.—
sp.stage: [Puts down a Card, and turns another.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: King face't, Eight wins, Ten loſes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Fire and Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what is the Captain vaniſh'd in his own Smoak?—Come, I Bett with you, Mr. Sharper; your Card loſes.

div.stage: Re-enter Captain, pulling in a Stranger, which he had fetch'd out of the Street.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir, do you think it poſſible to loſe a Trante & Leva a Quinſe-leva,—and a Sept-et-leva,—and never turn once

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: No ſure, 'tis almoſt Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ounds you lie, I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel. and all the Women.
sp.p: Ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p:
What the Devil, had I to do among theſe Land-Rats?—Zounds, to loſe Forty Pounds for nothing, not ſo much as a Wench for it; Ladies, quotha,—a Man
had as good be acquainted with Pick-pockets.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the Captain has frighted the Women out of their Wits,—now to keep my Promiſe with my Lord, tho' the Thing has but an ill Face, no Matter.
sp.l: They join together to Enſlave us Men,
And why not we to Conquer them again.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Enter Sir James on one ſide, and Lady Reveller on the other.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: SIR James, what have you done with the Rude Porpois?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: He is gone to your Uncle's Apartment, Madam, I ſuppoſe.—I was in Pain till I knew how your Ladiſhip did after your Fright.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Really, Sir James, the Fellow has put me into the Spleen by his ill Manners. Oh my Stars! That there ſhould be ſuch an unpoliſhed Piece of Humane Race, to be in that Diſorder for loſing his Money to us Women.—I was apprehenſiev he would have beat me, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, your Ladiſhip muſt impute his ill Breeding to the Want of Converſation with your Sex; but he is a Man of Honour with his own, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I hate out of faſhion'd Honour.—Bu • where's the Company, Sir James? Shan't we play again?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: All diſperſs'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Come, you and I'll go to Picquet then.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh I'm tir'd with Cards, Madam, cann't you think of ſome other Diverſion to paſs a chearful Hour?—I cou'd tell you One if you'd give me leave.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Of your own Invention? Then it muſt be a pleaſant One.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh the pleaſanteſt one in the World.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What is it I pray?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Love, Love, my Dear Charmer.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh Cupid! How came that in your Head?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis in my Heart, and except you pity me the Wound is Mortal.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, is Sir James got into my Lord Worthy's Claſs?—You that could tell me I ſhould not have ſo large a Theme for my Diverſion, were you in his Place, ha, ha, ha; what, and is the Gay, the Airy, the Witty, Inconſtant, Sir James overtaken? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Very true, Madam,—you ſee there is no jeſting with Fire.—Will you be kind?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Kind? What a diſmal Sound was there?—I'm afraid your Feaver's high, Sir James, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: If you think ſo, Madam, 'tis time to apply cooling Medicines.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, what Inſolence is this? The Door lock'd! What do you mean Sir James?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh 'tis ſomething indecent to Name it, Madam, but I intend to ſhow you.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Unhand me, Villain, or I'll cry out.—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Do, and make your ſelf the Jeſt of Servants, expoſe your Reputation to their vile Tongues,—which if you pleaſe ſhall remain ſafe within my Breaſt; but if with your own Noiſe you Blaſt it, here I bid Defiance to all Honour and Secrecy,—and the Firſt Man that enters dies.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? Inſtruct me Heaven—Monſter, is this your Friendſhip to my Lord? And can you wrong the Woman he Adores.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ay, but the Woman does not care a Souſe for him; and therefore he has no Right above me; I love you as much, and will poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! hold—Kill me rather than deſtroy my Honour—what Devil has Debauch'd your Temper? Or how has my Carriage drawn this Curſe upon me? What have I done to give you cauſe to think you ever ſhou'd ſucceed this hated Way.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Why this Queſtion, Madam? Can a Lady
that loves Play ſo paſſionately as you do—that takes as much Pains to draw Men in to loſe their Money, as a Town Miſs to their Deſtruction—that Careſſes all Sorts of People for your Intereſt, that divides your time between your Toylet and the Baſſet-Table; (can you, I ſay, boaſt of Innate Virtue?—Fie, fie, I am ſure you muſt have gueſs'd for what I Play'd ſo Deep—we never part with our Money without Deſign—or writing Fool upon our Foreheads;—therefore no more of this Reſiſtance, except you would have more Money.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! horrid.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: There was Fifty Guineas in that Purſe, Madam—here's Fifty more; Money ſhall be no Diſpute.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: [Strikes it Down.] Periſh your Money with your ſelf—you Villain—there, there; take your boaſted Favours, which I reſolv'd before to have Repaid in Specie; Baſeſt of Men I'll have your Life for this Affront—what ho, within there.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Huſh—Faith, you'll Raiſe the Houſe. [Lays hold on her.] And 'tis in Vain—you are mine; nor will I quit this Room till I'm Poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Raiſe the Houſe, I'll raiſe the World in my Defence, help, Murther, Murther,—a Rape, a Rape—

div.stage: Enter Lord Worthy from another Room with his Sword Drawn.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha! Villain, unhand the Lady—or this Moment is thy laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Villain, Back my Lord—follow me.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: By the Bright Sun that Shines you ſhall not go—no, you have ſav'd my Virtue, and I will preſerve your Life—let the vile Wretch be puniſh'd by viler Hands—yours ſhall not be Prophan • d with Blood ſo Baſe, if I have any Power—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Shall the Traytor Live?—Tho' your Barbarous Uſage does not Merit this from me, yet in Conſideration
that I Lov'd you once—I will Chaſtiſe his Inſolence.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Once—Oh! ſay not once; do you not Love me ſtill? Oh! how pure your Soul appears to me above that Deteſted Wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: [Peeping.] It takes as I cou'd Wiſh—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yet how have I been ſlighted, every Fop preferr'd to me?—Now you Diſcover what Inconveniency your Gaming has brought you into—this from me wou'd have been unpardonable Advice—now you have prov'd it at your own Expence.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I have, and hate my ſelf for all my Folly—Oh! forgive me—and if ſtill you think me Worthy of your Heart—I here Return you Mine—and will this Hour Sign it with my Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: How I Applaud my ſelf for this Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Oh! the Tranſporting Joy, it is the only Happineſs I Covet here.
sp.l: Haſte then my Charmer, haſte the long'd-for Bliſs.
The only Happy Minutes of my Life is this.
sp.p: Sir James. Ha, ha, ha, ha, how am I Cenſur'd now for doing this Lady a iece of Service, in forcing that upon her, which only her Vanity and Pride Reſtrain'd.
sp.l: So Bluſhing Maids refuſe the Courtd Joy,
Tho' wiſhing Eys—and preſſing Hands Comply,
Till by ſome Stratagem the Lover Gains,
What ſhe deny'd to all his Amorous Pains.

div.stage: As Sir James is going off, enter Lady Lucy meeting him.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, Lady Lucy!—Having Succeeded for my Friend, who knows but this may be my Lucky Minute too?—Madam, you come Opportunely to hear.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Stand off Baſeſt of Men, I have heard too much; coud'ſt thou Chuſe no Houſe but this to Act thy Villanies in? And cou'd'ſt thou fairly offer Vows to me, when thy Heart, Poiſon'd with vicious Thoughts, harbour'd this Deſigns againſt my Family?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Very fine, Faith, this is like to be my Lucky
Minute with a Witneſs; but Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Offer not at Excuſes, 'tis height of Impudence to look me in the Face.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Egad ſhe Loves me—Oh! Happy Rogue—this Concern can proceed from nothing elſe. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: My Heart till now unus'd to Paſſion ſwells with this Affront, wou'd Reproach thee—wou'd Reproach my ſelf, for having Harbour'd one favourable Thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Why did you, Madam?—Egad I owe more to her Anger than ever I did to her Morals.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Ha! What have I ſaid?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The only kind Word you ever utter'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Impoſture, know to thy Confuſion that I did love the, and fancy'd I Diſcover'd ſome Seeds of Virtue amongſt that Heap of Wickedneſs; but this laſt Action has betray'd the Fond Miſtake, and ſhow'd thou art all o'er Feign'd.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Give me leave, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Think not this Confeſſion meant to advance thy Impious Love, but hear my Final Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Egad I muſt hear it—I find for there's no ſtopping her.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: From this Moment I'll never—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: (Clapping his and before Her Mouth.) Nay, nay, nay, after Sentence no Criminal is allow'd to Plead; therefore I will be hear'd—not Guilty, not Guilty. Madam, by—if I don't prove that this is all a Stratagem, Contriv'd, Study'd, Deſign'd, Proſecuted, and put in Execution, to reclaim your Couſin, and give my Lord Poſſeſſion—may you Finiſh your Curſe, and I Doom'd to Everlaſting Abſence—Egad I'm out of Breath—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! Cond'ſt thou prove this?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I can, if by the Proof you'll make me Happy; my Lord ſhall Convince you.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: To him I will refer it, on this Truth your Hopes Depend.
sp.l: In Vain we ſtrive our Paſſions to Conceal,
Our very Paſſions does our Loves Reveal;
When once the Heart, yields to the Tyrants Sway,
The Eyes or Tongue will ſoon the Flame Betray.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I was never out at a Critical Minute in my Life.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Sago and Two Bailiffs meeting Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Hearkee, Miſtreſs, is my Wife here?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Truly I ſhant give my ſelf the Trouble of ſeeking her for him; now ſhe has loſt all her Money—your Wife is a very Indiſcreet Perſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I'm afraid I ſhall find it ſo to my Coſt.

sp.speaker: Bailiffs.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, we cann't wait all Day—the Actions are a Thouſand Pound—you ſhall have time to ſend for Bail, and what Friends you Pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: A Thouſand Pound? [Enter Mrs. Sago.] Oh! Lambkin have you Spent me a Thouſand Pound.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Who, I Pudd? Oh! undone for Ever—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Pud me no Pud,—do you Owe Mr. Tabby the Mercer Two Hundred Pounds? Ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I, I, I, don't know the Sum Dear Pudd—but, but, but I do Owe him ſomething; but I believe he made me Pay too Dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! thou Wolfkin inſtead of Lambkin—for thou haſt Devour'd my Subſtance; and doſt thou Owe Mr. Dollor the Goldſmith Three Hundred Pound? Doſt thou? Ha, ſpeak Tygreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Sure it cann't be quite Three Hundred Pound. [Sobbing]

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Thou Iſland Crocodile thou—and doſt thou Owe Ratsbane the Vintner a Hundred Pound? And were thoſe Hampers of Wine which I receiv'd ſo Joyfully ſent by thy ſelf, to thy ſelf? Ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Puddy—I, I, I, beg your Pardon. [Sobbing.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: And why didſt not thou tell me of them? Thou Rattle-Snake?—for they ſay they have ſent a Hundred times for their Money—elſe I had not been Arreſted in my Shop.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Be, be, be, becauſe I, I, I was afraid, Dear Puddy. [Crying.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: But wer't not thou afraid to Ruin me tho, Dear Pudd. Ah! I need ask the, no more Queſtions, thou Serpent in Petticoats; did I Doat upon thee for this? Here's a Bill from Calico the Linnen-Draper, another from Setwell the Jeweller—from Coupler a Mantua-Maker, and Pimpwell the Milliner; a Tribe of Locuſts enough to undo a Lord Mayor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I hope not, truly, Dear, Dearey, I'm ſure that's all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: All with a Pox—no Mrs. Jezebel, that's. not all; there's Two Hundred Pound Due to my ſelf for Tea, Coffee and Chocolet, which my Journey-man has Confeſs'd fince your Roguery came out—that you have Imbezell'd, Huſwife, you have; ſo, this comes of your keeping Quality Company—e'en let them keep you now, for I have done with you, you ſhall come no more within my Doors I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Kill me rather; I never did it with Deſign to part with you, indeed Puddy. [Sobbing.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, no, I believe not whilſt I was Worth a Groat. Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: How! Mrs. Sago in Tears, and my honeſt Friend in Ruffins Hands; the meaning of this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Sir James—my Hypocritical Wife is as much a Wife as any Wife in the City—I'm Arreſted here in an Action of a Thouſand Pound, that ſhe has taken up Goods for, and Gam'd away; get out of my ſight, get out of my ſight, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Indeed and indeed. [Sobbing.] Dear Puddy but I cannot—no, here will I Hang forever on this Neck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Help, Murder, Murder, why, why, what will you Collar me?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Right Woman, I muſt try to make up this Breach—Oh! Mr. Sago, you are unkind—'tis pure Love that thus Tranſports your Wife, and not ſuch Baſe Deſigns as you Complain of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and ſhe run me in Debt out of pure Love to no doubt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: So it was Pudd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: VVhat was it? (Ha Miſtreſs) out of love to me that you have undone me? Thou, thou, thou, I don't know what to call thee bad enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: You won't hear your Keckey out, Dear Pudd, it was out of Love for Play,—but for Lo, Lo, Love to you, Dear Pudd; if you'll forgive me I'll ne'er play again. (Crying and Sobbing all the while.)

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, now, Sir, you muſt forgive her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: What, forgive her that would ſend me to Jayl?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: No, no, there's no Danger of that, I'll Bail you, Mr. Sago, and try to Compound thoſe Debts.—You know me Officers.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.p: Very well, Sir James, your Worſhip's Word is ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: There's your Fees, then leave here your Priſoner, I'll ſee him forth coming.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.p: With all our Hearts; your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Ah thou wicked Woman, how I have doated on thoſe Eyes! How often have I kneel'd to kiſs that Hand! Ha, is not this true, Keckey?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes, Deary, I, I, I, I do confeſs it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Did ever I refuſe to grant wbatever thou ask'd me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, never, Pudd.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago,
sp.p: Might'ſt thou not have eaten Gold, as the Saying is? Ha?—Oh Keecky, Keecky!

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Leave Crying, and wheedle him, Madam, wheedle him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I do confeſs it, and cann't you forgive your Keckey then that you have been ſo Tender of, that you ſo often confeſt your Heart has jump'd up to your Motuh when you have heard my Beauty prais'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p:
So it has I profeſs, Sir James,—I begin to melt,—I do; I am a good-natur'd Fool, that's the Truth on't: But if I ſhould ſorgive you, what would you
do to make me Amends? For that Fair Face, if I turn you out of Doors, will quickly be a cheaper Drug than any in my Shop.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And not maintain her half ſo well;—promiſe largely, Madam. [To Mrs. Sago.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I'll Love you for ever, Deary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: But you'll Jigg to Covent-Garden again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, indeed I won't come within the Air on't, but take up with City Acquaintance, rail at the Court, and go Twice a Week with Mrs. Outſide to Pin-makers-hall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: That would rejoice my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: See, if the good Man is not ready to weep; your laſt Promiſe has conquer'd.—Come, come, Buſs and be Friends, and end the Matter.—I'm glad the Quarrel is made up, or I had had her upon my Hands. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Pudd, don't you hear Sir James, Pudd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I can hold no longer,—yes, I do hear him,—come then to the Arms of thy n'own Pudd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jam.
sp.p: Now all's well; and for your Comfort Lady Reveller is by this Time married to my Lord Worthy, and there will be no more Gaming I aſſure you in that Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Joys upon Joys. Now if theſe Debts were but Accommodated, I ſhould be happier than ever; I ſhould indeed Kickky.

sp.speaker: Sir Jam.
sp.p: Leave that to me, Mr. Sago, I have won Part of your Wife's Money, and will that Way reſtore it you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I thank you, good Sir James, I believe you are the Firſt Gameſter that ever Refunded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Generouſly done,—Fortune has brought me. off this Time, and I'll never truſt her more.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: But ſee the Bride and Bridegroom.

div.stage: Enter Lord Worthy and Lady Reveller, Lady Lucy, Buckle, Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: This Match which I have now been Witneſs to, is what I long have wiſh'd, your Courſe of Life muſt of Neceſſity be chang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, Sir James here!—Oh if you love me, my Lord let us avoid that Brute, you muſt not meet him.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh, there's no Danger, Madam.—My Lord, I wiſh you Joy with all my Heart; we only quarrell'd to make you Friends, Madam, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What, am I trick'd into a Marriage then?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Not againſt your Will, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: No, I forgive you; tho' had I been aware of it, it ſhould have coſt you a little more Pains.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I wiſh I could return thy Plot, and make this Lady thine, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Then I ſhould be paid with Intereſt, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: My Fault is Conſideration you know, I muſt think a little longer on't.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And my whole Study ſhall be to improve thoſe Thoughts to my own Advantage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I wiſh your Ladiſhip Joy, and hope I ſhall keep my Kickey to my ſelf now.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my Heart Mr. Sago, ſhe has had ill Luck of late, which I am ſorry for.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: My Lord Worthy will confine your Ladiſhip from Play as well as I, and my Injunction will be more caſie when I have your Example.

sp.speaker: Buclke.
sp.p: Nay 'tis Time to throw up the Cards when the Games out.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard, Captain Hearty, Lovely and Valeria.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, Sir James, the Danger's over, we have doubled the Cape, and my Kinſman is Sailing directly to the Port.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: A Boon Voyage.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis done, and my Heart is at Eaſe.—Did you ever ſee ſuch a perverſe Baggage, look in his Face I ſay, and thank your Stars, for their beſt influences gave yon this Husband.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Will not Valeria look upon me? She us'd to be more Kind when we have ſiſh'd for Eals in Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lovely, is it thee? And has natural Sympathy forborn to inform my Senſe thus long?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How! how! This Lovely? What does it 〈◊〉 the Enſign I have ſo carefully avoided!

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the ſame; I hope you may be brought to like a Land Soldier as well as a Seaman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And, Captain, have you done this?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Faith, ſhe was too whimſical for our Element; her hard Words might have Conjur'd up a Storm for ought I know—ſo I have ſet her aſhore.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What, my Uncle deceiv'd with his Stock of Wiſdom? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Here's ſuch a Coupling, Mrs. Alpiew, han't you a Month's Mind?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: Not to you I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I was but in Jeſt, Child, ſay nay when you're ask'd.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The principal Part of this Plot was mine, Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Wou'd 'twas in my Power to hang you for't. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And I have no Reaſon to doubt you ſhould repent it, he is a Gentleman, tho' a younger Brother, he loves your Daughter, and ſhe him, which has the beſt Face of Happineſs in a married State; you like a Man of Honour, and he has as much as any one, that I aſſure you, Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Well, ſince what's paſt is paſt Recal I had as good be ſatisfied as not, therefore take her, and bleſs ye together.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: So now each Man's Wiſh is Crown'd, but mine with double Joy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Sir Richard, let's have a Bowl of Punch, and Drink to the Bridegroom's good Voyage to Night,—ſteady, ſteady, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I'll take a Glaſs with you Captain,—I reckon my ſelf a Bridegroom too.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I doubt Kickey won't find him ſuch. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Well,—poor Keckky's bound to good Behaviour, or ſhe had loſt quite her Puddy's Favour.
sp.l: Shall I for this repine at Fortune?—No.
I'm glad at Heart that I'm forgiven ſo.
Some Neighbours Wives have but too lately ſhown,
When Spouſe had left 'em all their Friends were flown.
Then all you Wives that wou'd avoid my Fate.
Remain contented with your preſent State
